thread.title: KAWS x NIKE: stanton street courts transformed as part of ‘new york made’ initiative
thread.title_full: KAWS x NIKE: stanton street courts transformed as part of ‘new york made’ initiative

posts.author: peter corboy I designboom
posts.title: KAWS x NIKE: stanton street courts transformed as part of ‘new york made’ initiative
posts.text:
KAWS x NIKE: stanton street courts transformed as part of 'new york made' initiative nov 11, 2016 KAWS x NIKE: stanton street courts transformed as part of 'new york made' initiative 

NIKE has collaborated with artist and designer KAWS to drench new york’s stanton street basketball courts in color. the mural is part of the wider ‘new york made’ project, celebrating the opening of NIKE’s new five storey SoHo store. 
the installation is part of the wider ‘new york made’ project 


NIKE’s ‘new york made’ campaign sees the worldwide athletic brand work alongside NYC’s parks and recreation department to set in motion a number of city-wide events and installations honoring the city, and the iconic brand’s new york roots. ‘new york made:stanton street courts’ is the first in the series, and features a collaboration with popular artist KAWS as he transforms the stanton street courts with a vast, floor-wide mural. the completion of the piece coincides with the opening of NIKE’s new digitally connected, 55,000 square foot store in SoHo. 
the completion of the piece coincides with the opening of NIKE’s 55,000 square foot store in SoHo. 


brooklyn-based brian donnelly (KAWS) designed the mural to embody NIKE’s dedication to athleticism, community, culture and collaboration. ‘I always think about when I was young and the things I had interaction with, whether it was skateboard graphics or magazines, and how art reached me. I’ve been conscious of how my work disseminates and reaches people. It could be a canvas in a museum…or it could be a court, a wall or a t-shirt,’ says KAWS. ‘I like the idea of public art because it reaches people in a casual way, and when they aren’t necessarily looking for it.’ 
the mural aims to embody NIKE’s dedication to athleticism, community, culture and collaboration 


the mural takes is a pastiche of coloured shapes and lines, intersecting and contrasting across the court. in the foreground, two elmo-inspired silhouettes face off against each other — not dissimilar to KAWS’ elmo/cookie monster ‘BFF’ design — featuring donnelly’s trademark crossed out eyes motif. the artist explains that his approach to working on the larger scale court was in practice similar to the one he takes on more conventional, canvas-based projects. what changes is the relationship between court and player — the fact that this would be an interactive work was forefront in his mind: ‘I wanted to find the sweet spot where it works visually and functionally — how it’s broken up by the game’s lines and works with my images. it will have an intimate effect on the players that use the court.’ 
the fact that this would be an interactive work was forefront in donnelly’s mind 
KAWS has a longstanding relationship with the iconic sportswear brand 
donnelly is brooklyn-based, but originally hails from new jersey 
the mural is a first in a series of city-wide initiatives to celebrate the opening of NIKE’s new location

thread.title: These Are the 12 Coolest Sneakers of the Week
thread.title_full: These Are the 12 Coolest Sneakers of the Week

posts.title: These Are the 12 Coolest Sneakers of the Week
posts.text:
These Are the 12 Coolest Sneakers of the Week 
From Jordan, Adidas, Nike, Reebok, and more. Adidas By Pete Forester Nov 11, 2016 
This weekend, many are going to jump into retail therapy—something that might be the right choice for you, too! There's no shortage of dope sneakers releasing, but the two highlights are collaborations: John Elliott's understated pair of Nikes and Palace's irreverent collection with Adidas. Reebok also presents two collaborations, each with a unique texture that makes them really special. Adidas' work with Parley for the Oceans finally becomes available in the near future for those who have been looking forward to it, but don't expect that to be an easy buy—that's what everyone's looking at this week.   Nike x John Elliott Zoom LeBron Soldier 10 
John Elliott continues bringing his mind to Nike's LeBron styles in the first official collab between the man and the brand. His Zoom LeBron Soldier 10 features the expected platinum upper with a hit of orange in the sole, an artfully designed ombé treatment on the throat, and a glowing outsole for a surprise in the dark. 
Release: 11/11 
$200, available exclusively at Nike's new SoHo store Nike Flyknit Racer "Earth Tones" 
The perennial favorite, Nike's Flyknit Racer, returns this weekend in a new "Earth Tones" colorway. The subtle, heathered shifts of blue all over the upper make for a look that's sophisticated, sitting on a silhouette that's more than earned its street cred. This is a good choice if you don't have many sneakers in your closet and are looking to add more. 
Release: 11/11   Reebok x Hall of Fame Question Mid "Black Braid" 
Hall of Fame has joined Reebok in its celebration of the Question's 20th anniversary, reaching into Allen Iverson's style history for inspiration. This time they looked to his signature cornrow hairstyle, a real statement at the time of his career, developing it into this "Black Braids" interpretation of his shoe. The sneakers use braided suede through the length of the shoe, while the rest of the upper is done up in tonal suede and leather that sits on a while midsole and black outsole. 
Release: 11/11 
$175, rise45.com Reebok x Solebox Classic Club C 85 "Year of the Court" 
Using a classic tennis shoe and tennis inspirations, Solebox brings a welcome new texture to Reebok's Club C 85. The two brands looked to the overlapping leather of a tennis racket handle, replicating that look and feel over the entire upper. The shoe is almost exclusively turquoise, with hits of grey at the heel and red stitching through the sole. The understated silhouette with a color as special as turquoise makes this sneaker something truly different. 
Release: 11/11   Nike Sock Dart "Wool" 
Continuing the ongoing trend of woolen sneakers are this week's "Wool" Sock Darts from Nike, which are exclusive to U.K.-based sneaker store size? Here's the thing: Sock Darts can't literally be made of wool on account of their socklike construction—but the weave of the material has been heathered to reflect that look. The style is a hard sell for winter because of its breathability but at least these will give you that cozy look. 
Release: 11/11 
£100‎, size.co.uk Nike Dunk High SB Red Velvet 
If it's beginning to look a lot like the winter holidays, you can thank Nike. Velvet is always a welcome addition and here we find it in saturated red on a pair of Dunk His. These are a festive pair that will serve you all year, whether you're getting into the holiday spirit or not. 
Release: 11/11   Adidas 350 Suede 
Historically, Adidas' 350 has rarely been seen in the U.S. And for good reason: It was never meant to be. The sneaker was created for the Asian market in the 1980s, but was brought back recently for global consumers. This version of the 350 is an exclusive to UK retailer size? and features a retro colorway with minimal construction. A fresh classic and a classy sneaker. 
Release: 11/11 
£80‎, size.co.uk Greats x Lardini Wooster 
One of the crown jewels for Greats brand has been its relationship with Nick Wooster, the unopposed street-style god. Their ongoing collaborations have resulted this week in a pair of slip-ons created with Italian suiting specialist Lardini. The mismatched pairs come in two fabric styles, donegal tweed and herringbone tweed, and are just formal enough to fool your boss to thinking that you're not wearing sneakers. 
Release: 11/11   Adidas x Palace Indoor Suede / Leather 
Palace continues its ongoing collaborative relationship with Adidas in the new collection "All Day Ich," a play on the urban legend that A.D.I.D.A.S. stands for "All day I dream about soccer." The comedic advertising supports relatively conventional court shoes in old-school Adidas colors. These are agile, light sneakers that deliver the message of athleticism without the bulk of basketball shoes. 
Release: 11/12 
$130, adidas.com Adidas x Packer Shoes NMD 
Packer Shoes is celebrating its legacy of almost 100 years in the footwear industry with a retro-inspired colorway of one of this era's favorites. The Adidas NMD is made up in colors that reflect classic 1980s tracksuits, and features Adidas' Primeknit on the upper. The release for these will be relatively limited—a bolder sneaker that you'll still be able to grab if you try hard enough. 
Release: 11/12

Here's What's Next for Nike KD 9s First image of the "Obsidian" colorway surfaces. By Brendan Dunne 
What else is on the way for the Nike KD 9 besides that Christmas pair previewed this week? It looks like Nike will soon release this pair, an obsidian colorway that hasn't been through the cycle of leaks that these shoes are used to. 
From this vantage point there don't appear to be any special material applications on this KD 9 —the shoe looks to be standard issue mesh and Flyknit.

thread.title: Nike Delays SoHo Store Opening
thread.title_full: Nike Delays SoHo Store Opening

posts.author: Jessica Iredale
posts.title: Nike Delays SoHo Store Opening
posts.text:
Nike's SoHo store's opening was delayed due to permits. Lexie Moreland 
NEW YORK – Nike has been forced to delay the opening of its 55,000-square-foot store in SoHo here, planned for today, due to permits. This is after a week of promoting the store with press walkthroughs and a party Nov. 9. The company issued this statement: “We look forward to bringing New Yorkers the best of Nike at our new Soho store. Due to permitting issues, the store will not open to the general public as planned on Friday, November 11 th . We will communicate the new opening date as soon as possible. Scheduled product launches and consumer events are postponed until opening.”

thread.title: 5 Things To Know About The Apple Watch Series 2 Nike+
thread.title_full: 5 Things To Know About The Apple Watch Series 2 Nike+

posts.author: Kristen Henning
posts.title: 5 Things To Know About The Apple Watch Series 2 Nike+
posts.text:
The product is $369 for the 38mm version and $399.99 for the 42m one. Nike invited FN to test the watch on a 3 mile run and here are 5 features and facts to know. Apple Watch Series 2 Nike+, $369. Courtesy of Nike. Built-in GPS tracks your pace, route and distance. With just a tap, you can view your pace, distance and heart rate. If desired, the watch will talk to you along the way, to let you know when you’ve hit your mileage goals. 
2. If you’ve been using the Nike+ Run Club app, the watch functions with the same capabilities, so you can run sans phone. If you need motivation to pound the pavement, you can set run reminders and even share your run summaries to challenge friends. There is even a feature to fist bump friends and fellow users. Nike+ Running Trial Zone. Courtesy of Nike. 
3. The watch also syncs with Siri commands and will adapt to coaching plans. Tips and guidance are also offered from Nike coaches and athletes. 
4. If you’re interested in swimming, the Series 2 is water resistant 50 meters. 
5. You can personalize your progress and fitness goals, using Activity Rings, Heart Rate, Stopwatch and Weather features. A look at multiple Nike Air Zoom Structure 20 colorways for men and women. Courtesy of Nike.
